questions.question:
Question 1: A child, upon disturbing a beehive, had several stings. After a few minutes, he developed 
shock, respiratory failure, and vascular collapse. What is the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of anaphylaxis following a bee sting. This is an example of 
IgE-mediated reaction or type 1 hypersensitivity. Injurious immune reactions are called hypersensitivity reactions. There are four types of 
hypersensitivity reactions. Immediate (Type 1) hypersensitivity is also called allergic reactions. They are induced by 
environmental antigens (allergens) that stimulate strong TH2 responses and IgE production in 
genetically susceptible individuals. IgE coats mast cells by binding to Fcg receptors. Reexposure to the allergen leads to cross-linking 
of the IgE and FcRI, activation of mast cells, and release of mediators. The principal mediators 
are histamine, proteases, and other granule contents like prostaglandins and leukotrienes 
and cytokines. It occurs in two phases: immediate phase and late phase. The mediators are responsible for the 
immediate vascular and smooth muscle reactions and the late-phase reaction (inflammation). The 
clinical manifestations may be local or systemic and range from mildly annoying rhinitis to fatal 
anaphylaxis. The image given below shows the sequence of events in immediate hypersensitivity. 280 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 2: Arthus reaction is caused by which of the following process?
questions.explanation:
Arthus reaction is characterized by a localized area of tissue necrosis due to 
immune-complex-mediated (type III hypersensitivity reaction) vasculitis in the skin. This reaction can be produced experimentally by intracutaneous injection of antigen in a 
previously immunised animal that contains circulating antibodies against the antigen. As the 
antigen diffuses into the vessel wall, it binds with the preformed antibody, and immune 
complexes are formed locally. These complexes precipitate in the vessel walls and cause fibrinoid 
necrosis.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 42-year-old female patient presents with ptosis, diplopia, and progressive muscular 
weakness towards the end of the day. She has improvements in symptoms after administering 
edrophonium. The given clinical condition is an example of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical condition is highly suggestive of myasthenia gravis. It is an example of a type II 
hypersensitivity reaction. Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease that is usually associated with autoantibodies 
directed against acetylcholine receptors. In Type II hypersensitivity, antibodies react with 
antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause. These 
antibodies destroy cells, trigger inflammation, or interfering with normal functions.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 6-year-old child abruptly develops malaise, fever, nausea, oliguria, and smoky, cola-colored 
urine 2 weeks after recovery from a sore throat. He is found to have periorbital edema and 275 
Sold by @itachibot mild hypertension. Urine examination shows dysmorphic red cells and red cell casts in the 
urine with mild proteinuria. Which type of hypersensitivity is responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nephritic syndrome due to post-streptococcal 
glomerulonephritis. This is an example of a type III hypersensitivity reaction. In type III hypersensitivity, immune complexes may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit 
an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement. The pathogenesis of systemic immune 281 
Sold by @itachibot complex disease can be divided into three phases: • Formation of immune complexes • Deposition of immune complexes • Inflammation and tissue injury This results in various manifestations like vasculitis, glomerulonephritis and arthritis. Examples of type III hypersensitivity reactions: • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis • Systemic lupus erythematosus • Reactive arthritis • Polyarteritis nodosa • Serum sickness • Arthus reaction • Farmer’s lung • Hypersensitivity pneumonitis • Type II lepra reaction • Henoch–Schonlein purpura The image given below shows the mechanism of type III hypersensitivity reactions.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 25-year-old man with a fever and chronic cough is administered 0.1 mL of purified protein 
derivative intradermally over the forearm. After a few hours, the injection site appears as 
follows. Which of the following does this represent?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario shows a positive tuberculin test. It is a classical example of type IV 
or delayed or cell-mediated hypersensitivity reaction. 282 
Sold by @itachibot Tuberculin test involves intradermal injection of purified protein derivative (PPD, also called 
tuberculin), a protein-containing antigen of the tubercle bacillus. In a previously sensitized 
individual, reddening and induration of the site appear in 8 to 12 hours, reach a peak in 24 to 72 
hours, and thereafter slowly subside. Morphologically, delayed-type hypersensitivity is characterized by the accumulation of 
mononuclear cells, mainly CD4+ T cells and macrophages, around venules. The cell-mediated type 
of hypersensitivity is caused by inflammation resulting from cytokines produced by CD4+ T cells 
and cell killing by CD8+ T cells.

questions.question: Question 6: True about anaphylactoid reaction are all except:
questions.explanation:
Anaphylactoid reactions are those reactions that are similar to the anaphylactic reactions but are 
not IgE mediated. These reactions are caused by direct degranulation of the mast cells or 
basophils, which causes the release of mediators. Unlike the classic anaphylaxis which occurs on re-exposure to the allergen, the anaphylactoid 
reaction can occur even on the first exposure. The most common agents that can cause an 
anaphylactoid reaction include NSAIDs and radiocontrast media. In 2014, World Allergy Organisation has introduced two new terms: • Immunologic anaphylaxis - It includes anaphylactic reactions mediated by IgE, IgG (in animals), 
and immune complex/ complement-mediated reactions. • Non-immunologic anaphylaxis (previously called anaphylactoid reaction) - It includes reactions 
caused by agents which cause massive degranulation of mast cells or basophils in the absence of 
immunoglobulin. The image given below shows the sequence of events in type 1 hypersensitivity reaction. 283 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following autoimmune diseases are not mediated by antibodies?
questions.explanation:
Rheumatoid arthritis is mediated by T cells, not antibodies. Antibody-mediated diseases: • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia • Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura • Pemphigus vulgaris • Vasculitis caused by ANCA • Goodpasture syndrome • Myasthenia gravis • Acute rheumatic fever • Graves disease • Pernicious anemia • Insulin resistant diabetes T cell-mediated diseases: • Rheumatoid arthritis • Multiple sclerosis • Psoriasis • Type 1 diabetes mellitus • Inflammatory bowel disease • Contact sensitivity Note: In T cell mediated diseases, although the role of T cells have been demonstrated, antibodies 
may also be involved in tissue injury.

questions.question: Question 8: Which gene is most frequently implicated in autoimmunity?
questions.explanation:
PTPN22 gene is most frequently implicated in autoimmunity. PTPN22, which encodes the protein tyrosine phosphatase, is associated with the following 
conditions: • Rheumatoid arthritis • Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) • Type 1 diabetes Because these disorders have a fairly high prevalence, PTPN22 is said to be the gene that is most 
frequently implicated in autoimmunity. Option A: Mutations in FOXP3 cause a systemic autoimmune disease called IPEX (immune 
dysregulation, polyendocrinopathy, enteropathy, X-linked). 284 
Sold by @itachibot Option C: Polymorphisms in the gene encoding for NOD2 are associated with Crohn's disease. Option D: AIRE mutation is associated with the autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 
1 (APS-1).

questions.question:
Question 9: During development, thymic cells recognizing self-antigens are removed to prevent 
autoimmunity. Which gene among the following is involved in the process?
questions.explanation:
The above process is called central tolerance and the AIRE (AutoImmune REgulator) protein is 
necessary for this process. Immature self-reactive T and B lymphocyte clones recognize self-antigens during their maturation 
in the central lymphoid organs (thymus for T cells, bone marrow for B cells). They are killed or 
rendered harmless. The removal of self reacting T lymphocytes in the thymus is called negative selection/ deletion. For 
this process, AIRE protein is needed. Mutations in the AIRE gene results in autoimmune 
disorders (autoimmune polyendocrinopathy). B cells undergo a process called receptor editing. When developing B cells encounter an antigen, it 
formulates a change in the receptor that makes the antigen unrecognizable. Self-reacting B cells 
can also undergo apoptosis.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is responsible for autoimmunity in Epstein-Barr virus infection?
questions.explanation:
Autoimmunity in Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) infection is the result of polyclonal B cell activation. Microbes may induce other abnormalities that promote autoimmune reactions. Some viruses, 
such as EBV and HIV, cause polyclonal B-cell activation, which may result in the production of 
autoantibodies. The role of infections in autoimmunity is exemplified by the following: • Molecular mimicry of antigenic cross-reactivity: The structural similarity of the microbial 
antigens and self-antigens. Rheumatic heart disease is an example in which streptococcal proteins 
cross-react with myocardial proteins causing myocarditis. • Upregulation of co-stimulatory molecules by infectious organisms. • Polyclonal B cell activation: Caused by EBV and HIV, resulting in the production of 
autoantibodies. • Alteration of tissue antigens: Infections may alter tissue self-antigens so that they activate T cells 
and lose the property of self-tolerance.

questions.question:
Question 11: Homogeneous or diffuse nuclear staining pattern may reflect antibodies to all the following 
except:
questions.explanation:
Homogeneous or diffuse nuclear staining does not reflect antibodies to RNA. The nucleolar 
pattern of staining represents antibodies to RNA. 285 
Sold by @itachibot Antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) are directed against antibodies to: • DNA • Histones • Nonhistone proteins bound to RNA • Nucleolar antigens The most widely used method for detecting ANAs is indirect immunofluorescence. The pattern of 
nuclear fluorescence suggests the type of antibody present in the patient’s serum.

questions.question: Question 12: What type of cell is the lupus erythematosus cell?
questions.explanation:
The lupus erythematosus (LE) cell is a phagocytic neutrophil or macrophage. Nuclei of damaged cells react with ANAs, lose their chromatin pattern, and become homogeneous 
to produce LE bodies or hematoxylin bodies. Phagocytic neutrophils or macrophages engulf the 
denatured nucleus of an injured cell. Demonstration of LE cells in vitro was used in the past for 
the diagnosis of SLE. The image below shows a lupus erythematosus (LE) cell.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 32-year-old lady presents with the following finding. On further investigations, anti-ds DNA 
and anti-Smith antibodies are found to be positive. Which of the following is not seen in the 
given clinical condition? 278 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical picture is highly suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). In this 
condition, lymphocytic infiltration in the salivary gland is not seen. However, this finding is seen 
in Sjogren's syndrome. If cell nuclei are exposed to anti-nuclear antibodies (ANAs), they can bind to them. The nuclei of 
damaged cells react with ANAs, lose their chromatin pattern, and become homogeneous. They are 
called lupus erythematosus (LE) bodies or hematoxylin bodies. 286 
Sold by @itachibot An acute necrotizing vasculitis involving capillaries, small arteries, and arterioles with fibrinoid 
necrosis is seen in SLE. Central penicilliary arteries in the spleen may show concentric intimal 
and smooth muscle cell hyperplasia, producing so-called onion-skin lesions.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following is not a part of the IgG4 spectrum?

options.b: It is due to oxidase deficiency

questions.explanation:
Celiac disease is not an IgG4-Related disease. IgG4-related disease (IgG4-RD) is a newly recognized constellation of disorders characterized by 
tissue infiltrates dominated by IgG4 antibody-producing plasma cells and lymphocytes, 
particularly T cells, storiform fibrosis, obliterative phlebitis, and usually increased serum IgG4. IgG4-RD spectrum includes: • Mikulicz syndrome - enlargement and fibrosis of salivary and lacrimal glands • Riedel thyroiditis • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis • Autoimmune pancreatitis • Inflammatory pseudotumors of the orbit, lungs, and kidney 287 
Sold by @itachibot Immunodeficiency Syndromes
